awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Dynamics of Daily-weekly Boreal Spring InterTropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) Shifts over the Eastern Pacific Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
Textbook diagrams of the world's wind patterns show a narrow band around the equator where the tradewinds of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres flow together, causing rising motions, deep clouds, and heavy rain. This simple, static picture has served as a powerful conceptual framework to explain the existence of the band, know as the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), and its connection to the global atmospheric circulation and the energy balance of earth's climate. But the real-world ITCZ is not static, and while theories developed from the static picture can account for its north-south seasonal migration and longer-term shifts accompanying ice ages, they may lack key ingredients needed to explain short-term ITCZ variability.

Work performed here focuses specifically on the dynamics of short-term ITCZ fluctuations identified in a recent study of the Eastern Pacific in Northern Hemisphere Spring (Haffke et al 2016). The fluctuations include shifts from the Northern to the Southern Hemisphere and splitting events in which a single ITCZ is replaced by a pair of convergence zones, one on either side of the equator.  The shifts and splits take place over the course of a few days and the project seeks to account for them in terms of changes in the winds of the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL, the lowest kilometer or so of the atmosphere).  

The Principal Investigator (PI) hypothesizes that these fluctuations are driven by relatively subtle changes in the large-scale pressure gradients affecting the region of the ITCZ.  The pressure gradients lead to changes in the north-south component of the ABL winds near the equator, and the nonlinear advection of moisture and meridional momentum by these winds causes rapid ITCZ shifting or splitting.  This hypothesis is tested and explored through a combination of observational analysis, focused on the longitudinally averaged ABL momentum equation, and idealized computer simulations.

The broader impacts of the work include educational activity conducted through Iowa State University's Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) program targeted at middle and high school science teachers.  Teachers from central Iowa schools participate in research related to this project over six summer weeks and also participate in a seminar series and regular discussion group on the pedagogy of science teaching. Later in the project the PI and students from his department visit the schools of the teachers in the program for all-day events devoted to the science of weather and climate.  The events include presentations and hands-on activities, some using rotating tanks to demonstrate the dynamics of weather systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is a critical component to Earth’s climate system. The ITCZ is a narrow region where the tropical trade winds from the northern and southern hemispheres collide, producing deep convective clouds and heavy rainfall with global impacts. Textbooks often paint an over-simplified picture of the ITCZ that follows the Sun’s slow seasonal migration. However, interesting weather occurs in and near the ITCZ, which can cause sudden changes in its latitudinal location, especially over the east Pacific Ocean. This grant explored the relationships between the lower atmosphere and these fast north-south movements of the ITCZ over the east Pacific Ocean. The focus was on the boreal spring season when the east Pacific ITCZ shifts on daily to monthly timescales.

We began with observational analyses of these springtime ITCZ shifts, providing strong evidence that the near surface winds surrounding the ITCZ are highly impacted by slow (weekly–monthly) and fast (daily) processes. Through an analysis of what controls daily to monthly time variations in winds for different configurations of the ITCZ, we demonstrated that spatial contrasts in surface pressure, called the pressure gradient force (PGF), is the dominant factor in controlling near surface winds. While these results agree with past studies of the slowly varying climatological ITCZ, this is the first time they have been shown for daily to monthly ITCZ variability. We also corroborated the idea that nonlinear wind factors help explain the erratic behavior of the springtime ITCZ.

Given the leading role of the PGF in daily to weekly ITCZ shifts from our first study, our second study determined that northern and southern hemisphere ITCZs over the east Pacific are significantly impacted by positive and negative air-sea feedback mechanisms called wind-evaporation-sea surface temperature (SST) feedbacks. Positive WES feedbacks are controlled by north-south PGF variations and they dominate prior to the development of the ITCZ. On the other hand, negative WES feedbacks are controlled by mixing of stronger winds from above the surface and they dominate during and after the development of the ITCZ. This study was the first to suggest that both WES feedbacks operate on weather timescales and in the ITCZs of both hemispheres. The state-of-the-art Community Atmosphere Model 6 accurately depicts the presence of these positive and negative WES feedbacks. However, the model shows a one to two week delay in when these WES feedbacks peak in strength, implying that winds and wind convergence respond more to ITCZ convection rather than the other way around, as seen in observations.

In a third study, we explored what controls precipitation associated with daily to weekly east Pacific ITCZ shifts. We demonstrated that large weather systems called convectively coupled waves can help explain a large portion of east Pacific ITCZ precipitation variability, especially in the southern hemisphere where rainfall is more sporadic compared to the northern hemisphere. We postulated that rainfall is more dependent on these waves propagating through the region, especially from the central Pacific Ocean. 

In our last study supported by this grant, we devised a theory by which low drizzling clouds and a cold tongue of water near the equator can alter the PGF, and subsequently, the ITCZ. The results support the observed preference of a northern hemisphere-dominant ITCZ in the east Pacific and provide a new, wind-based (“dynamical”) link between the ITCZ, low clouds, and the equatorial cold tongue, all three of which have plagued climate models for three decades.

Through our broader impacts, we guided two graduate students through their Ph.D. research, mentored research projects for three undergraduate students and one high school teacher. In addition, we co-led two workshops training over 50 teachers at the middle school, high school, and 2- and 4-year college levels on how to utilize rotating water tank experiments and online climate tools into their classrooms through the annual Earth Educators Rendezvous conference. Lastly, we incorporated rotating tanks and online weather and climate tools into the instruction of often too-theoretical atmospheric dynamics courses at Iowa State University and used these interactactive tools in outreach activities reaching over 150 students at Urbandale High School and the Black Girls Dive Foundation, and 9 educators from Historically Black Colleges and Universities who participated in STEMSEAS, a ship-based, 10 day exploratory experience.
